column1: Noisy-le-Grand (pronounced [nwa.zi.lə.ɡʁɑ̃]) is a commune in the eastern suburbs of Paris
column2: France. It is located 15.2 km (9.4 mi) from the centre of Paris. The commune of Noisy-le-Grand is part of the sector of Porte de Paris
column3: one of the four sectors of the "new town" of Marne-la-Vallée.

column1: Some of the postmodern architecture in the commune has been used as a shooting location in movies including Brazil and The Hunger Games.
The name Noisy comes from Medieval Latin nucetum
column3: after the walnut trees (French: noyers) covering the territory of Noisy-le-Grand in ancient times.
was added in the Middle Ages
column4: probably to distinguish Noisy-le-Grand from the smaller settlement of Noisy-le-Sec
column5: which was sometimes referred to as Nucenum Minus ("Noisy the Small").

column1: The canton of Noisy-le-Grand comprises two communes: Noisy-le-Grand and Gournay-sur-Marne.
Previously Star Airlines (now XL Airways France) had its headquarters in the Immeuble Horizon building in the commune. Cédric Pastrour
column3: said that the company chose the Noisy site because the airline did not yet know which airport
column4: Charles de Gaulle Airport or Orly Airport
column5: would serve as the airline's base
column6: and that the Noisy site was equidistant to both airports. Pastour added that the Noisy site had access to the A4 and the A86 autoroutes and was close to the Francilienne
column7: and that the costs in the Noisy area were lower than the costs in the airport area.

Noisy-le-Grand is served by two stations on Paris RER line A: Noisy-le-Grand–Mont d'Est station and Noisy–Champs station.
Noisy-le-Grand is also served by Les Yvris–Noisy-le-Grand station on Paris RER line E.
